content: End-to-end neural models have advanced question answering, but recent studies suggest they assume answers and evidence are in close proximity in a single document. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) is a new model that combines evidence from multiple documents. It includes a coarse-grain module for interpreting documents with respect to the query and finding relevant answers, and a fine-grain module that scores candidate answers by comparing their occurrences across all documents with the query. The CFC achieves a state-of-the-art result of 70.6% accuracy on the Qangaroo WikiHop multi-evidence question answering task. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) achieved a state-of-the-art result of 70.6% accuracy on the Qangaroo WikiHop multi-evidence question answering task, outperforming the previous best by 3% accuracy. This model focuses on multi-evidence QA, aggregating evidence from multiple documents to answer questions effectively. The Coarse-grain Fine-grain Coattention Network (CFC) achieved a new state-of-the-art result on the blind Qangaroo WikiHop multi-evidence question answering task, with a focus on selecting candidate answers based on support documents and a query. The CFC combines coarse-grain reasoning, building a summary of support documents, and fine-grain reasoning, matching specific contexts with the query to assess candidate relevance. The model utilizes hierarchical attention to integrate information from support documents and candidates. The CFC achieves a new state-of-the-art result on the blind Qangaroo WikiHop test set with 70.6% accuracy, surpassing previous best by 3%. It also improves accuracy on the TriviaQA task by 3.1% for exact match and 3.0% for F1. The attention hierarchies in the CFC modules focus on distinct parts of the input, enabling better representation of long documents. The effectiveness of the model is evaluated on two tasks: multi-evidence question answering on the WikiHop dataset and multi-paragraph extractive tasks. The Qangaroo WikiHop task involves multi-evidence question answering by linking entities in a document corpus with a knowledge base, creating a bipartite graph. This dataset facilitates the study of question answering by using support documents to form paths between entities in the graph. The Qangaroo WikiHop task involves selecting the correct candidate answer from a set of plausible candidates based on support documents. The task uses unmasked and masked versions of WikiHop to evaluate candidate answers. Data is tokenized using Stanford CoreNLP and embeddings from GloVe and character ngrams are utilized. Symbolic query relations are split into words for analysis. The CFC model achieves state-of-the-art results on both masked and unmasked versions of WikiHop, with a new best accuracy of 70.6% on the blind test set. Ablation study on WikiHop dev set shows the impact of removing different modules and using different techniques. Reranking with the CFC consistently improves performance, regardless of the correctness of the initial answer set.
